course_title: Community Development: Local and International Practices

learning_outcomes.description: Explain and critique key concepts and practices of community development, including participation, social justice and working with diversity, in both local and international contexts;
Facilitate group processes using appropriate community development methodologies and techniques;
Apply community development principles and practices in collaborative settings, demonstrating competence through interactive engagement, facilitation and written reflection;
Analyse and compare diverse approaches to development practice, identifying their strengths, limitations and contextual appropriateness;
Evaluate the ethical dimensions of community development work and articulate the implications for professional practice.

assessments.due_date:
2/03/2026 - 23/03/2026

In week 1, you will be assigned to a Home Group (designated by a letter). Your Home Group allocation determines when all your assessments and activities are due. Please see the Study Guide on Blackboard Ultra for specific dates.
assessments.task_description:
Task summary:

Working in your assigned group, you will complete three parts:

 

Part A: Create a plan (before your allocated week)

·        Design an opening activity (a warm-up, icebreaker, or energiser)

·        Write a plan explaining your activity and why you chose it

·        Use the marking criteria as your guide for what to include

·        Format: your choice

 

Part B: Deliver the activity (during your allocated week)

·        As a group, run your 10-minute opening activity in the weekly workshop

 

Part C: Write a reflection (after your allocated week)

·        Reflect on how the activity went

·        Use the marking criteria to structure your reflection

·        Format: your choice

 

Submission requirements:

Submit Part A (your plan) AND Part C (your reflection) together

Maximum length: 2 A4 pages total (both parts combined)

Due: one week after your workshop presentation


Please see the Study Guide and Blackboard Ultra for further details on this task, including the marking rubric.


Use of Generative Artificial Intelligence and Machine Translation in this task

Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Translation (MT) are emerging tools that may support students in completing this assessment task. Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.  Additional resources are available through UQ AI Student Hub.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your assessment electronically by the due time, on the due date.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
For this task you will read an assigned article or book chapter, submit a written response to it using a process called “Outsider Witnessing”, and then facilitate a discussion on the reading with your peers, using this process, during class time.

Note: For this task, the in-class component is group-based and ungraded. The written component is individual and assessable.

Please see the Study Guide and Blackboard Ultra for further details on this task, including the marking rubric.

Use of Generative Artificial Intelligence and Machine Translation in this task

Students may appropriately use AI and/or MT in completing this assessment task. Students must clearly reference any use of AI or MT in each instance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.  Additional resources are available through UQ AI Student Hub.

assessments.due_date:
27/04/2026 - 18/05/2026

This task does not have a written component. It is an oral interview that will take place individually with the course coordinator, on the day of your in-class facilitated activity.
assessments.task_description:
This assessment comprises two components:

•       A one-hour community-based learning experience facilitated by your home group for your peers

•       An individual 15-minute reflective conversation with the course coordinator

Note: For this task, the in-class component is group-based and ungraded. The oral interview that follows is individual and assessable and is directly linked to the in-class component.

Please see the Study Guide and Blackboard for further details on this task, including the marking rubric.

Use of Artificial Intelligence and Machine Translation in this task

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies for the ungraded facilitation activity, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. Additional resources are available through UQ AI Student Hub.

AI use is not permitted for the graded 15-minute reflective conversation. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools, via the 15-minute graded reflective conversation.
assessments.submission_guidelines: It is an oral interview that will take place individually with the course coordinator, on the day of your in-class facilitated activity.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
POSTPONED - Week 1: Introduction and orientation

Please see Study Guide on Blackboard for updated schedules.

We will use this seminar class to begin exploring what "community development" (CD) is and in particular, how it relates to - and differs from - other responses to social issues. How we spend our time together will be the other focus of our discussion, including how our classes will be run, as well as our assessment and formal requirements for the course. You will also learn about the people you will be spending time with throughout the semester. [Note: In this week you will be assigned your "home groups" which relate directly to your assessment for the course. If you cannot make Week 1 for any reason it is vital you connect with the Course Coordinator to ensure allocation to a group, as assessment commences in Week 2.]


Learning outcomes: L01, L02

How we spend our time together will be the other focus of our discussion, including how our classes will be run, as well as our assessment and formal requirements for the course. You will also learn about the people you will be spending time with throughout the semester. [Note: In this week you will be assigned your "home groups" which relate directly to your assessment for the course. If you cannot make Week 1 for any reason it is vital you connect with the Course Coordinator to ensure allocation to a group, as assessment commences in Week 2.]

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Putting "community" into development

Traditional development often overlooks the people it aims to serve. This week explores how 'the participatory turn' has challenged this, positioning communities as essential partners in development processes. We'll examine how community development differs from other development approaches, introduce the participatory paradigm, and explore key methods for data collection and analysis—including participatory rural appraisal and visual methods. This begins our deep dive into community development practice. Assessment 1 commences this week.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2: Putting "community" into development Traditional development often overlooks the people it aims to serve. This week explores how 'the participatory turn' has challenged this, positioning communities as essential partners in development processes. We'll examine how community development differs from other development approaches, introduce the participatory paradigm, and explore key methods for data collection and analysis—including participatory rural appraisal and visual methods. This begins our deep dive into community development practice. Assessment 1 commences this week.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: Putting "development" into community

This class challenges traditional top-down approaches to community development by exploring communities as co-learners - active participants in shaping their own growth. Through examining community-based education, participatory learning principles, and group facilitation basics, you'll discover how to support (rather than direct) community development processes. Essential preparation for Assessment 3. Note that Assessment 2 commences this week.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3: Putting "development" into community This class challenges traditional top-down approaches to community development by exploring communities as co-learners - active participants in shaping their own growth. Through examining community-based education, participatory learning principles, and group facilitation basics, you'll discover how to support (rather than direct) community development processes. Essential preparation for Assessment 3. Note that Assessment 2 commences this week.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4: Putting voice into participation

Participation becomes transformative when it moves from data collection to genuine dialogue. This week explores storytelling and narrative practice as participatory methods that centre community voice and lived experience. We'll examine how dialogical approaches create space for communities to share, reflect, and generate knowledge on their own terms—extending our methods toolkit beyond visual techniques.


Learning outcomes: L03, L04, L05

We'll examine how dialogical approaches create space for communities to share, reflect, and generate knowledge on their own terms—extending our methods toolkit beyond visual techniques.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6: EASTER FRIDAY Public Holiday

No class on Friday, April 3rd, 2026. Our class falls on the Easter Friday public holiday and so there will be no SOSC2288 Seminar this week. Some students may still have assessment items due this week. Please refer to the Study Guide for specific assessment dates for your Home Group.

Note: Mid-semester break occurs between Week 6 and 7 in Sem 1, 2026. See the UQ academic calendar for details.

Please refer to the Study Guide for specific assessment dates for your Home Group. Note: Mid-semester break occurs between Week 6 and 7 in Sem 1, 2026. See the UQ academic calendar for details.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5: Technology on community terms

Community development doesn't reject technology—it asks who controls it and for what purpose. This week explores digital participatory methods like photovoice and participatory video that put technological tools in community hands. We'll also examine how emerging technologies—social media and AI—are reshaping community work, considering both their disruptive effects and their potential when communities drive their use.

Learning outcomes: L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5: Technology on community terms Community development doesn't reject technology—it asks who controls it and for what purpose. This week explores digital participatory methods like photovoice and participatory video that put technological tools in community hands. We'll also examine how emerging technologies—social media and AI—are reshaping community work, considering both their disruptive effects and their potential when communities drive their use.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7: Putting bodies into participation

Community development often privileges talk and text, yet we learn with our whole bodies, not just our minds. This week introduces embodied methods—theatre, art, dance, and music—as powerful participatory tools that engage communities in different ways. We'll examine how embodied practices create space for collective expression and help transform individual experiences into shared agendas for change. This expands our methods toolkit to honour multiple ways of knowing and participating

Learning outcomes: L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8: Reserve Week

Welcome to Queensland, where, in the past few years our Semester 1 timetable has been disrupted by global pandemics, floods and cyclones. I am keeping this week in reserve in case we need to re-work our timetable. Please do not book anything else in for this time. If we do not need to adjust the timetable you can use this “free” week to meet with your group and continue preparing for assessment 3.

Learning outcomes: L03, L04

I am keeping this week in reserve in case we need to re-work our timetable. Please do not book anything else in for this time. If we do not need to adjust the timetable you can use this “free” week to meet with your group and continue preparing for assessment 3.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9: Application of CD - the Social and Political dimensions

We've explored participatory methods—now we turn to where and how they're applied. This week examines community development across two key dimensions: social development (community planning, service delivery, and connection work) and political development (power analysis, community action, and advocacy). We'll consider what makes these activities genuinely developmental—and how even familiar practices like service delivery become transformative when grounded in CD principles. The political dimension requires us to start with power: who has it, how it operates, and how communities can challenge and reshape it. Assessment 3 commences this week.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 9: Application of CD - the Social and Political dimensions

We'll consider what makes these activities genuinely developmental—and how even familiar practices like service delivery become transformative when grounded in CD principles. The political dimension requires us to start with power: who has it, how it operates, and how communities can challenge and reshape it. Assessment 3 commences this week.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 10: Application of CD - the Economic and Local dimensions

Can communities work within existing economic systems, or must they reimagine what economy means? This week explores community economic development across its conservative and radical possibilities—from enterprise development that adapts to market logics, to solidarity economies that fundamentally reclaim economic relationships. We then turn to local cultural development, asking whether place-based work still matters in an increasingly globalized world. Together, these dimensions challenge us to consider: what does it mean to build community power in economic and cultural terms?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 10: Application of CD - the Economic and Local dimensions

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11: Application of CD - Indigenous & Multicultural dimensions

Who holds knowledge about community? This Seminar challenges Western dominance in community development by centering First Nations approaches. We'll explore what Australian Indigenous and Torres Strait Islander peoples teach about community relationships and development, and what it means to work respectfully and accountably in these spaces. We then examine cross-cultural practice more broadly: how do we work when multiple cultures, histories, and worldviews occupy shared space? This requires humility, protocol, and a willingness to follow.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 11: Application of CD - Indigenous & Multicultural dimensions

We'll explore what Australian Indigenous and Torres Strait Islander peoples teach about community relationships and development, and what it means to work respectfully and accountably in these spaces. We then examine cross-cultural practice more broadly: how do we work when multiple cultures, histories, and worldviews occupy shared space? This requires humility, protocol, and a willingness to follow.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12: Application of CD: Environmental & Survival dimensions

What happens when development threatens survival? This week examines environmental CD in contexts where industries like mining and forestry create paradoxical impacts—employment alongside destruction, progress alongside displacement. We then explore survival development: how CD responds when basic needs (water, shelter, health) and disaster recovery become urgent. These newest and most challenging dimensions of CD practice ask us to work where communities face existential threats—from slow environmental degradation to sudden catastrophic loss.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 12: Application of CD: Environmental & Survival dimensions

learning_activities.topic:
From CV to CD: Entering the CD field

How do you turn learning into livelihood? This final class focuses on entering the community development field: where CD work happens, how to find opportunities, what employers are looking for, and how to position yourself as a practitioner. We'll explore pathways into paid and voluntary CD roles, discuss essential skills and networks, and consider how to carry forward the participatory principles you've learned. We'll also reflect on how the methods and dimensions we've explored fit together in real practice.

Learning outcomes: L03, L04
